title: Pressure - determine density of water in pool

content.question: A student measures the absolute pressure at various depths below the surface of the water in a swimming pool. The distance below the surface is also measured for each location at which the pressure is measured. Which of the following correctly indicates and justifies a method that could be used to determine the density of the water?

choices.label: Divide the pressure at the very bottom of the pool by the product of the depth of the water and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> because the pressure at the surface of the pool is zero.
Divide the pressure at the very bottom of the pool by the depth of the water because the pressure at the surface of the pool is zero.

Graph pressure as a function of distance below the surface and divide the slope of the line by <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> because pressure is given by <math alttext="P equals, P sub atmosphere plus rho g h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mtext>atm</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mi>g</mi><mi>h</mi></math>.

Graph pressure as a function of distance below the surface. The density of the water is the slope of the line because pressure is given by <math alttext="P equals, P sub atmosphere plus rho g h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mtext>atm</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mi>g</mi><mi>h</mi></math>.
